speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise on behalf of the people in the Digby, Annapolis area who have seen the economic spin-offs from CFB Cornwallis slowly eroding.
Over the past year we have seen the continuous reduction of jobs, resulting in the closing of businesses, the threat of school closures, and the downsizing of a base to a station. All this activity is taking place without the government being honest in stating that the base is gradually closing.
Today we have a group of non-partisan politicians from Nova Scotia presenting to the government, parliamentarians of all stripes both in the Senate and the House of Commons, the need to find some activity for Cornwallis until the Department of National Defence starts recruiting English speaking new recruits again.
This is a cruel process to impose on the people of South West Nova. People already have been adversely affected by the bad economic policies of this government in this area.
I call on the government to stop this downsizing and to act on the proposals put forth in the past and today by this group of non-partisan politicians from Nova Scotia to keep Cornwallis working both for National Defence and the people of South West Nova.

Mr. Speaker, there are increasing signs that the Canadian economy is expanding. Production rose during the first quarter, and exports reached record levels last March. Operating profits also rose during the first quarter of this year.
In May employment went up by 0.3 per cent. The manufacturing sector showed the most significant improvement with an increase of 41,000 jobs over the past two months.
In 1991, despite economic problems, business productivity increased by 1.5 per cent, the biggest annual gain since 1985. As a result the cost of doing business went down, which in twin makes us more competitive.
What is particularly welcome, is the permanent aspect of Canada's economic recovery. Thanks to this government's economic policies, economic recovery will accelerate during the months to come and, more important, we have the assurance of durable and non-inflationary growth of the Canadian economy.

Mr. Speaker, Canada is home to the largest population of Sikhs living outside India. Canadian Sikhs have declared this week a week of mourning in commemoration of those who lost their lives during the vicious attack by the Indian army on the Golden Temple at Amritsar which took place on June 4, 1984.
The Indian government's two-day military assault resulted in the deaths of thousands of Sikh men, women and children. To this day the Indian government contin-

June 10, 1992
ues to engage in activities that violate the most fundamental of human rights.
Amnesty International reports that Sikh prisoners have been detained for months or years without trial, that incidents of torture during interrogation are common, and that the arrest and detention of some detainees remain unacknowledged for weeks or months.
This is a damning record for a country that billed itself as one of the world's largest democracies.
Canada has very good relations with India. I would ask the minister of external affairs to urge the Indian government to cease its persecution of Indian Sikhs. India's actions against its own population are deplorable and thought should be given that present or future bilateral aid to India be made conditional on the commitment of the Indian government to solve its internal problems peacefully.

Mr. Speaker, now that the last chance constitutional talks are getting started, the federal government and the provinces should agree to enshrine in the Constitution a provision that guarantees the growth, promotion and protection of Canada's linguistic minorities. It is essential to amend the Constitution to include a clause recognizing the equal status, rights and privileges of francophone and anglophone linguistic communities in New Brunswick. Equality must extend to the right to have separate educational institutions and the cultural institutions that are needed to protect and promote these communities.
I hope the Government of Quebec will agree, without reservation, that our new Constitution makes it possible for Francophone minorities across the country to take their rightful place in Canada's great bilingual multicultural family.

Mr. Speaker, the free trade agreement again has proven itself to be a great asset to Canada in a trade dispute with the United States.
Yesterday the minister of trade announced that a dispute settlement panel voted unanimously in favour of Canada's position on yet another important trade issue. Canada has strongly opposed the U.S. position over how to deal with the interest costs in determining the North American content of Canadian built Japanese cars.
We have said from the beginning that these costs were indeed a part of the calculation and once again we have been proven right.
This victory will have very positive direct results on the GM Suzuki combined car assembly factory in Ingersoll, Ontario. The decision is also an important step down the road toward a positive resolution to the Honda dispute.
This panel decision again demonstrates the FTA dispute settlement mechanism works and works well.

Mr. Speaker, in September 1988 the government made an announcement which stated that it was going to construct a new residence building at the Emergency Preparedness Canada Training Centre in Amprior.
It was to be completed by December 1990. Nothing has been done yet. From time to time rumours have been floating around to the effect that the government was going to move the training centre to another location. In recent months this rumour has been very strong and seems to be coming from very valid sources.
The community was upset. The employees were upset. People from across Canada who had taken courses there were upset. Over the weekend the mayor of Amprior and I organized a meeting for Tuesday evening, June 9.
June 10,1992

Mayors, county councillors, other elected people and a large segment of the population and media came to the meeting. Recent publicity on last night's meeting obviously brought the rumour mongering to a halt because the Minister of Supply and Services as the regional minister sent a letter to the mayor late yesterday afternoon stating that the Emergency Preparedness Canada Training Centre would remain in Arnprior.
I congratulate all concerned and I thank the minister for his help.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, not only have we won an important dispute under the free trade agreement but we are winning in other international forums, as we said we would.
On behalf of the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, I am very pleased to inform this House that the International Court of Arbitration rendered a decision today in New York City on the Canada-France maritime boundary dispute. The decision has largely confirmed Canada's jurisdiction over the disputed waters located south of Newfoundland and St.Pierre and Miquelon. The court has awarded France very little of the area that it had claimed. France had claimed an area outside the 12 mile territorial sea of 13,703 square nautical miles. It was awarded 2,537 square nautical miles, part of it in the deep waters of the Laurentian Channel which contains virtually no fishery resources.
The elimination of the large disputed zone means that the management of the groundfish resources in subdivision 3PS is now under Canadian control.

Canada's only native run probation service will die this Friday and its case files will be handed over to the province of Manitoba if the Solicitor General will not renew its funding.
The Dakota Ojibway Probation Service has served native communities in southern Manitoba for seven
years, recording success levels 5 to 10 per cent higher than the provincial average, according to a University of Manitoba study.
Native parolees are counselled and supervised in their aboriginal languages, referred to drug and alcohol treatment programs in their own language, and receive guidance from their elders in a traditional way.
Manitoba is willing to continue funding on a 50/50 basis but the federal government refuses to renew funding because of a manufactured jurisdictional dispute with the province over probation services on reserves.
If the federal government could find just $180,000 out of its massive constitutional or PR budgets, it could fund this probation service for a whole year. If it had its priorities straight, it would fund the program permanently* * *

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today in New York the arbitration panel adjudicating the boundary dispute between Canada and France rendered a very important and historic decision.
The decision reassures Canada and the world that the position the Government of Canada has taken has been accepted. About one-sixth of the St.Pierre bank will be under the control of St.Pierre and Miquelon and the French, and less than 20 per cent of the claim made by France outside the territorial sea has been accepted.
There will be no groundfish controlled by France off the south coast of Newfoundland. It is in 3PS, an area depended upon by the fishermen of the south coast of Newfoundland. Canada has achieved effective control over this area and its management system will be held intact and unchallenged.

Mr. Speaker, I want to condemn this government for removing without notice funding for two important job training programs for mothers on social assistance in metro Toronto.

June 10, 1992
The government removed funding on April 1 for the YWCA's Focus on Change and the Dixon Hall Neighbourhood Centre's STEP program, and it did not give either program an opportunity to find alternate sources of funding.
By its decision to gear job training programs only to those who qualify for unemployment insurance payments-and I believe this program is the creation of the minister responsible for that area of the city-the government risks creating systemic barriers to job training and permanent welfare statistics out of these women.
If these two job training programs for sole support mothers are lost, choices for women will be seriously limited. The decision to cut funding defies reason and shows a lack of compassion.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Communications
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the member for Ahuntsic, I am very pleased, on behalf of my constituents and myself, to congratulate Julie Payette who is originally from Ahuntsic, on being chosen from among 5,330 male and female candidates as Quebec's first and Canada's second woman astronaut-no doubt the youngest woman ever to participate in the space shuttle program.
Ms. Payette is an important symbol not only for women but for all young Canadians, whether they live in Quebec or any other province of Canada.
I want to point out the great scientific, intellectual, artistic and athletic abilities of my riding's new heroine. Good luck, Julie. We are very proud and honoured in my riding.
Hear, hear.

Mr. Speaker, on April 1, I met with the Prime Minister regarding Mrs. Henriette Haddad, a Canadian citizen taken hostage in Lebanon in 1985 and not heard of since.
This meeting was held in the presence of Mrs. Haddad's son and friends of the family where the Prime Minister promised he would do everything possible to locate Mrs. Haddad and obtain her release.
To the Prime Minister's credit, he did write to the presidents of Syria, Lebanon and Iran requesting their co-operation and the government also sought UN assistance.
Consequently I was shocked yesterday to read a report that authorities were working to obtain the release of the last two western hostages in Lebanon, two German citizens, with no mention of Mrs. Haddad.
I plead with the government to follow this up immediately to make sure that Mrs. Haddad, the only Canadian hostage, is not forgotten and that a release is actively pursued.

Mr. Speaker, research and development lay the groundwork for industrial success and Canadian companies are proving that the policies of this government have provided an environment where innovative technology can flourish.
Since the implementation of increased patent protection for pharmaceuticals five years ago, Glaxo Canada Inc., based in Mississauga, has increased R and D funding to nearly $30 million annually.
Over the next five years, Glaxo expects to spend over $270 million on R and D in Canada. These investment levels far exceed the commitment undertaken by pharmaceutical manufacturers to spend 10 per cent of sales on R and D.
Increased investment has meant increased employment opportunities for Canadians as Glaxo's work force has increased from 400 to more than 1,000 in the past five years.
Glaxo's commitment to Canada continues. In April the company inaugurated new corporate headquarters in Mississauga and broke ground on the same site for a $70 million manufacturing facility slated for completion in 1995. I congratulate the people of Glaxo Canada Inc.-

The hon. member's time has expired.
June 10,1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister.
Yesterday the Prime Minister confirmed that the government was indeed considering spending $4.3 billion to acquire military helicopters designed for fighting Soviet submarines, a threat that no longer exists today. Furthermore, these helicopters would be made in Europe, contrary to what the Minister of National Defence suggested yesterday to reporters.
Does the Acting Prime Minister not find it strange that the government is preparing to spend billions of dollars to fight Soviet submarines, when next week he will dine with Boris Yeltsin, the President of Russia? At that time the Russian president will ask for money not to fuel his submarines but to feed his people.

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the minister also indicated yesterday that no decisions have been made on this matter.
Obviously we take into consideration the change in the global situation as we look at our requirements. It is important to recognize that what we are looking at are replacement helicopters for our search and rescue missions over the oceans.
I am sure my hon. colleagues would agree that is a very important mission for our Canadian Armed Forces. I think there were over 200 lives saved as a result of those missions in the past two years. We must have capable equipment.
On looking at any decisions of this nature we will take into account not only the global situation and the capability but obviously the cost effectiveness of whatever equipment may be required.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yesterday when asked about whether we even need these helicopters the Prime Minister said: "I have not the foggiest idea".
That is the problem with members of this government. They do not have the foggiest idea what they are doing in this file and many other files. When we ask for money for
Oral Questions
infrastructure they have none, but when it comes to high-tech toys they spend money like drunken sailors. Tb be fair, drunken sailors spend their own money, not taxpayers' money.
How come there is money for helicopters like that and none for infrastructure when a lot of experts say that of course we will need some helicopters sooner or later but not these very expensive helicopters? They are not needed any more to fight Soviet submarines.

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first, with respect, I think the hon. Leader of the Opposition would want to reflect on the words he used to describe sailors. Men and women who serve in our navy are honourable and outstanding representatives of this country.
Second, I would also suggest to my hon. colleague: Is he saying, for example, that we should not have safe, capable equipment to provide search and rescue over the oceans? Should we not have safe helicopters that we can provide the fisheries patrol which I know is so important to members from the eastern provinces?
All of these are ongoing tasks of our naval requirements. We will be going through a process of review. The Minister of National Defence will be making recommendations in due course to cabinet about what the most appropriate equipment should be, taking into account all factors in order to meet those needs.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the Deputy Prime Minister.
When asked about infrastructure programs the government has the habit of saying-and I have heard the Minister of Finance saying it in this House-that the municipalities do not have money to pay their one-third.
At the conference in Montreal the Federation of Canadian Municipalities did a survey and 87 per cent of the people there said that they were in favour of this program of one-third, one-third, one-third, and 83 per cent of them said they would have no problem finding the money to do the job at the moment. By a margin of five to one they said that the problems they were having in the cities today with their infrastructure were hurting business opportunities.

June 10, 1992
Oral Questions
What do we need more at this moment: to help our cities, to create jobs in Canada and not in Great Britain, or to buy expensive helicopters that are not needed, that type of helicopter, at this time?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. Leader of the Opposition knows very well the security of our nation is clearly the responsibility of the federal government. Our defence capability is clearly the responsibility of the federal government. Those are clear priorities the federal government has to observe and has to implement.
Obviously he knows very well that the kind of infrastructure program he is talking about is essentially the responsibility of the provinces and the municipalities. I indicated to the hon. member on many occasions that he wants to go on a spending spree. He wants to go on a spending spree, suggesting that the provinces put up one-third, the municipalities put up one-third and the federal government puts up one-third.
There is only one taxpayer. The priorities of this government are to respond effectively in those areas of responsibility and jurisdiction that are clearly within the domain of the federal government.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. It is not a matter of spending but a matter of priorities. Yesterday the Minister of National Defence said that those criticizing the government's priorities regarding the acquisition of the British helicopters were guilty of appeasement. What an outrageous analogy.
Are 1.5 million unemployed Canadians across Canada who want jobs guilty of appeasement? Is the mayor of Montreal who wants jobs for the unemployed in his city guilty of appeasement? Are one million children who line up at food banks guilty of appeasement? Are 8 million Canadians who do not have adequate sewer systems guilty of appeasement?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if I could iterate once again, I am sure my hon. colleague is quite aware of the national defence policy which came out last fall and was updated. It clearly set out what are the roles and responsibilities of national defence.
We have a budget within which we have to operate. Part of that budget goes for capital equipment. One of our approaches is to increase the amount of our existing approved budgets for capital equipment in order that our men and women will have the appropriate equipment. One of the projects within that existing budget is replacement helicopters.
This is a question of how we are going to deal with the issue within the Department of National Defence, recognizing that our budget has been constrained over the last few years and will continue to be constrained.
Nevertheless, we do believe that the replacement helicopters for search and rescue, for fisheries patrol, for drug interdiction, for all the new roles that our navy will be taking on, are very important priorities.

Mr. Speaker, in order of importance are the 1.5 million Canadians who are looking for work not important to this government?
What about the one million children right now who are lining up at food banks? Are those children important to this government? What about the eight million Canadians who do not have sanitary sewers?
We ask the government once again: Would it not be a better priority to put money into a public works program now to get Canadians working and help rebuild our cities? Is that not a question of real government priority?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, is the hon. member suggesting that the Government of Canada should put Armed Forces personnel into equipment that is unsafe?
The helicopters that are proposed to be replaced are 35 years old. Surely she should take that into consideration.
June 10, 1992

In order for our men and women to carry out their responsibilities, to carry out and preserve the security and integrity of the country, we need not only personnel but equipment to do the job.

Mr. Speaker, further on the helicopters, I give government members the benefit of the doubt and suggest that they do not know what they are talking about rather than suggest they are intentionally misleading the Canadian people.
The helicopters that are being proposed and publicly recommended by the chief of defence staff are EH-101 helicopters specifically designed for anti-submarine purposes. That is why they are so expensive: $91 million a crack.
Those helicopters are simply not justified now that the Soviet threat is over. I call on the Minister of National Defence or the associate minister to kill the program today.

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to make clear to my hon. colleague, who I know is a member of the national defence standing committee and is very knowledgeable in matters of national defence, that whatever choice of helicopter is made it has to meet certain requirements that we have. It has to be capable and it has to be cost effective.
The EH-101 has some of those capabilities. It may or may not be the helicopter that would come forward as a final proposal to cabinet. No decisions have been made. No recommendations have yet been made, and we are going to be looking at all these factors.
I think of the bottom line. I hope my hon. colleague would agree, because just recently in British Columbia there was an incident, a very sad incident, involving the use of one of our old Labrador helicopters. We have to move to replace them with modem, safe, effective equipment not only for our own men and women in the Armed Forces but to ensure we maintain the safety of Canadian lives that may be at risk from time to time on the oceans off both our coasts.

Mr. Speaker, if the government spent its defence dollars on maintaining equip-
Oral Questions
ment that was used for search and rescue instead of on cold war weaponry that is completely useless, then it would have the support of this side of the House.
Yesterday, in trying to defend the indefensible, the expenditure of $4.3 billion on these Soviet seeking helicopters, the Prime Minister said: "We must be ready to meet threats that affect the national interests of Canadians".
Will the Deputy Prime Minister not agree that with the end of the Soviet threat the national interest of Canadians is best served not by wasting $4.3 billion on these helicopters but on having Canadians fully employed, our young people properly educated, and our children properly fed?
And the NDP would wipe out the armed forces. An interesting policy.

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I feel the hon. member is really giving the wrong impression. It is not a choice of one or the other.
The question is within the Department of National Defence, within our budget which is allocated and which the hon. member approved at committee, how we will spend those moneys most effectively to meet our missions.
In the National Defence policy statement which we put out we talked about the new roles for the Canadian navy, not the old role of fighting the Soviet Union. We know that is gone, we all know that. There are new important domestic roles: the protection of sovereignty, the protection of our coastal resources, drug interdiction, search and rescue. All are important missions that I am sure all hon. colleagues would support us on.
We need to ensure we have the capabilities to provide those missions and to provide the equipment for them in the best and most cost effective manner.

Mr. Speaker, the minister must surely know that if the role is as she defines it, search and rescue, fishing patrols, then a totally different helicopter is required.
I come back to the Minister of Finance.

June 10, 1992
Oral Questions

How can the government justify this kind of expenditure when it was unable to find $40 million to finance summer employment programs or $2.7 million for the Court Challenges Program or $20 million for housing co-operatives?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, perhaps the hon. member recalls the budget when it came out earlier this year. Within that budget the government set out expenditure priorities for a whole range of activities.
One of those activities that is clearly within the federal government's responsibility and a major priority, is the defence of our country. Within our budget, which has been allocated despite the reductions we have had to take over the past few years, one of the priorities in terms of capital equipment is the provision of new modem helicopters which will enable us to undertake the tasks we have been mandated to do.
I am sure my hon. colleague would agree with that and will be working toward providing that equipment in the most cost-effective manner possible.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Justice. Canadians living in our large urban centres are becoming increasingly fearful over the rising tide of crime which is undermining both public safety and quality of life. In fact, since 1984 violent crime in Canadian cities has risen some 40 per cent.
Given that our national government spends very little on crime prevention programs in comparison with per capita figures of many other countries around the globe, when will the minister finally reverse this trend? When will she begin to lend greater support to existing preventative organizations like Block Parents and other possible creative solutions so we can assist municipalities in winning back their communities?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Government of
Canada does participate in these kinds of programs. We funded a research project recently by the Federation of Canadian Municipalities to develop strategies for crime prevention.
As the hon. member will know, if he has been in the House over the last few months, I have been working actively with the caucus of big city mayors of the Federation of Canadian Municipalities. I have been meeting with police chiefs across the country to develop a strategy to create a national strategic and co-ordinated approach toward the questions of urban crime, urban safety, broadly based urban justice issues.
I welcome the input of the hon. member on how he may be able to discharge that function more effectively. It does require the co-operation of all three levels of government, each exercising discretion in its own jurisdiction as effectively as possible.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the same minister.
A major component of that rising urban crime is directly related to the chronic problem of drug abuse. Unless local municipalities, police forces and community groups, which are on the firing line of this battle on drugs, get immediate and urgent assistance this war will never be won.
When will the government finally amend its proceeds of crime legislation so as to ensure that moneys secured from drug seizures, which last year alone amounted to over $38 million, will be shared with local municipalities and organizations rather than going exclusively into the federal coffers? It has been promised many times by this government. When will it finally act?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is not simply a question of legislation under the level of the federal government. The provinces themselves are extremely resistant to direct payments by the federal government to the municipalities in this area.
As my colleague, the Solicitor General, has indicated in the House on a number of occasions, we are reviewing this to try to find a way to answer that question.
I also point out that I think my hon. colleague exaggerates the amount of money that is available through the proceeds of crime to distribute.
June 10,1992

Recently we have established three task forces in Vancouver, Toronto and Montreal, the three major drug trafficking centres of the country, to make sure that we get the most benefit out of the proceeds of crime legislation. We are looking to maximize the receipts from the proceeds of crime. Then we can address the question that the member quite rightly raises of the fair and equitable distribution of those proceeds.
I would also point out that in fact the lion's share of the costs of implementing the drug legislation to fight drugs in Canada is borne by the federal government.

Mr. Speaker, my question is addressed to the Minister of Justice.
Canadians are tired of endless studies on the relationship between visible minorities and the justice system. We need people on the bench who share or at least understand the experience of visible minority youth in our big cities. What will it take for the minister to recognize this and when will she do something about it?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in 1987 our government established for the first time in Canada a Canadian judicial centre to provide education to federally appointed judges across this country. Among the kinds of courses that are offered are courses in gender sensitivity and in cultural sensitivity.
In addition I have worked very pro-actively to try and expand the range of people who sit on the federal bench. If the hon. member were to go through the law schools in most Canadian universities she would see that until recent years there is a remarkable absence of visible minorities graduating from law school.
She will also know that one must have been called to the bar for 10 years before being eligible to be appointed to the federal bench. I expect that within the next 10 to 15 years the variety of candidates available for judicial appointment will be much greater and much more consistent with the proportions of people in society in general.
Oral Questions
I welcome suggestions from anyone about competent and able people who would be capable to go to the bench and who could illustrate what has been one of my major priorities as Minister of Justice and that is inclusive justice to make the system reflective of all Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the President of the Treasury Board.
For five years we have been asking the government to enforce the Employment Equity Act in the Public Service. Why does the minister not stop dragging his feet and take action now?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I certainly do not agree with the hon. member's description of the work being done by Treasury Board.
I will give her some figures, I know opposition members are not very fond of statistics but it is the only way to evaluate the progress we have made. In each of the groups that were designated we have made significant progress. The recruitment rate for women, for instance, has gone up from 42.4 per cent in 1987 to 44.9 per cent in 1991. For native people, there was an increase from 1.8 per cent to 2 per cent; for the disabled, from 2.6 per cent to 3 per cent; and for visible minorities, from 2.7 per cent to 3.6 per cent, in 1991.
This kind of progress may not be satisfactory but it is significant.

Mr. Speaker, my question is addressed to the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
Over half a year ago, the task force on professional training in the arts in Canada delivered its report. This task force, as I am sure the minister remembers, was established in April 1990 by his ministry and the Ministry of Communications. It was recognized that improve-

June 10, 1992
Oral Questions
ments had to be made in professional training for the arts in Canada. Yet the minister and his department have not responded to this important report and recommendations.
Can the minister tell us when and if he will respond to the report on professional training of the arts in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the evaluation of that report is ongoing in the department. I have had conversations and contacts with the Minister of Communications who is responsible for the arts sector in Canada. I cannot give a definite date when we can respond or when we will, but we are well advised of the recommendation and are looking at it.

Mr. Speaker a supplementary question to the same minister.
Mr. Minister, your department through its labour force training programs play a vital-
Hon. members know that in this Chamber we do ask hon. members to put the question through the Chair. I know the hon. member would want to do that.

Mr. Speaker, through you to the minister. I am sure the minister is aware that his department through labour force training programs plays a vital role in the professional training of the artist.
Yet people in his department whose expertise is with the cultural sector are not having their contracts renewed. Arts organizations have not been able to meet with the minister or his deputy. In fact, it is being stated that the job of the department is to shut doors to the arts community, not open them, and that the minister has no interest in the arts.
Can the minister tell us if he has any commitment to the arts and if he recognizes the special needs of the artists as well as the important economic role the arts play?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, yes, I do.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
In 1968 the northern cod stock catch was 815,000 tonnes. Last year it was 127,000 tonnes. This year it is likely to be zero. The Minister of Fisheries and Oceans talked about the possibility of his having to close down the fishery for one year, two years or maybe five years.
This means that the plants are going to be closed, the doors locked, boats are going to be tied up and secured, and 30,000 fishermen and fisherpersons will have no jobs and no income.
I ask the minister what contingency funding does the government have to compensate for this lost income?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is a hypothetical question. No decision has been made in that regard.
Fishermen and plant workers in Newfoundland and Labrador can be reassured by the record of this government to help these persons when in need. Without conjecturing on what can happen in the future, the hon. member can be assured that if the circumstances call for measures to be taken to help these people, we will be true to our tradition as a Parliament and as a government and will do it.

Mr. Speaker, the government was responsible for managing the fishery for the last eight years. It has failed and it is responsible for the fallout.
The minister talks about a hypothetical situation. The government is preparing, as has been discussed in the House, to commit $4.3 billion to something that may or may not happen. By its own admission the government expects and is not prepared to commit one cent to it. That is not only inconsistent, it is also incredible.
I would like to ask the minister one more time, would he consider telling this House what contingency funding, what action plan he has for these Atlantic Canadians who are going to face a situation, possibly, that they have not faced in 500 years?
June 10, 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):

subtopic: THE LATE SENATOR GEORGE CLIFFORD VAN ROGGEN

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
subtopic: THE LATE SENATOR GEORGE CLIFFORD VAN ROGGEN
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise in the House today to speak on behalf of all British Columbians and to express our sadness at the loss Monday night of a great British Columbian, Senator George van Roggen, who died in Vancouver at the age of 70.
Senator van Roggen and I did not share the same party, but I think all members in this House agree that there are people in public life in this country who transcend the definitions of partisanship and who win the respect, admiration and affection of all who come to know them and have had the opportunity to work with them.
George van Roggen was part of a long tradition of British Columbians who have excelled both in the law and in public life. He not only lived up to that tradition but he advanced it.
He was bom of a Dutch family and attended the University of British Columbia for his undergraduate and law degrees. Despite a physical disability, he served his country in World War II with great distinction as a member of the Canadian Scottish Reserve.
As a young lawyer who practised law in Yukon, he often referred to his Yukon years as among the best of his years before the bar. Back in Vancouver he rose to a partnership in the very distinguished Vancouver firm of Douglas, Symes and Brissenden.
June 10, 1992

During his successful legal career, Senator van Roggen always held a passion for politics. For 30 years he nurtured the Liberal Party in British Columbia both provincially and federally. His many friends of all parties will remember his efforts and achievements to make politics more relevant to the concerns of all British Columbians and to ensure the quality of public debate and service.
Prime Minister Trudeau brought Senator van Roggen to Ottawa in 1971. Much is said these days about the Senate, but let me say that Senator van Roggen worked as hard as any person in Ottawa to bring B.C. concerns to the national stage.
His interest extended beyond just domestic issues. He thought deeply and wisely about Canada's role in the world. He served as chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs from 1974 to 1988 and served as co-chair and member for the Canadian Interparliamentary Committees for Europe and the United States. He was no less aware of Canada's potential role in Asia and travelled to Japan in 1976 as a member of a Canadian parliamentary delegation.
It was his devotion to the interests of British Columbia and his perspective on Canada's role in the world that made him an articulate spokesman for free trade. He may be best remembered recently for his support of the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement and his eloquent analysis of the threat to Canada of international protectionism.
We remember George van Roggen as a man of service, as a man of commitment and as a man of courage. I might just say that last evening when I talked to members of the British Columbia caucus about my plan to rise in the House today to pay tribute to George van Roggen, I was struck by the warmth and the spontaneity of their remarks about this remarkable man and how much they see him as really an outstanding figure on the national stage and how much they regret his loss.
That is a sentiment shared by all British Columbians and all members of this House who I know will join with me in extending personal condolences to his wife Jane and his two children Norman and Trish.

subtopic: THE LATE SENATOR GEORGE CLIFFORD VAN ROGGEN
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise to associate fully the members of the Official Opposition with, to use their own words, the warm and spontaneous tribute which the minister has paid to our colleague, the late Senator George van Roggen.
Senator van Roggen was hailed yesterday in the Senate by one of our colleagues as a prince of a man. He was refined but with a common touch. He was wise but not pompous. He was thoughtful, articulate and a thorough gentleman. He was highly esteemed and greatly respected among all our contemporaries.
The reason why Senator van Roggen earned that tribute, which I am sure we all share, was out of his deep conviction and his deep commitment to the future of Canada. His participation in the political process was of long standing. It was productive, imaginative and it was rewarded in due course by the possibility of participating in the upper Chamber. There he made his reputation in a very short time as a most capable chairman of the foreign relations committee of the Senate.
He took a leading part in the review of our trade policies in a way that not only has been evident in his participation in the free trade discussions, but on a much broader scale as well with his interest in Asia and the Pacific in particular which arose in part from his deep love and commitment to British Columbia.
As a fellow Vancouverite, I share his commitment to the interests of his native province and his native city and I want to associate very much with the minister's tribute to George van Roggen today. We will miss him. We will miss his wisdom, his very real courage in bearing a personal handicap. We want very much to send our condolences and our sympathy to Mrs. van Roggen and their two children on their loss, which is not only a personal one but a loss to all of Canada.

subtopic: THE LATE SENATOR GEORGE CLIFFORD VAN ROGGEN

Mr. Speaker, as a member of Parliament from the lower mainland of British Columbia, I had the privilege of knowing Senator George van Roggen and working with him as one of the senators from our province.
When you knew George van Roggen, you were struck by his tireless work for Canada. He was a man who was interested in Canada and Canadian affairs and was a tireless advocate of the positions he took.

June 10, 1992
Tributes
I knew him and worked with him on the Canada-U.S. Parliamentary Group, one of the most important groups we have in this Parliament. We get a chance to work with American senators and other members of Parliament in dealing with the great issues between us and the Americans.
Senator van Roggen had strong views on issues, especially the trade issue, and he advocated those views very effectively, to some of us on the other side almost too effectively, but he advocated them and one admired that and saw it as the work of a very good senator.
He was a long-time member of the B.C. and Yukon bar associations. I am told that at one point he was the only lawyer in the town of Whitehorse. Of course, he did that job very well.
He had a long-time practice with a large Vancouver law firm and he practised there, I am told, from 1957 until 1981. Mr. Speaker, you and I practised law in Vancouver over the same period and we shared memories, times and work with Senator van Roggen.
When he went to the Senate in 1981, he was interested in areas of foreign relations, trade, Asia Pacific, matters that really concerned the people of British Columbia. He took on those issues and advocated his position very effectively. To his wife Jane, son Norman and his daughter Trish, I want to extend the sympathy of the members of my party, the New Democratic Party, especially those members from British Columbia, for their loss and a loss to all of us of a very dear distinguished Canadian.

subtopic: THE LATE SENATOR GEORGE CLIFFORD VAN ROGGEN
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to add just a few comments about the loss of a very great British Columbian.
Senator van Roggen was a forthright, powerful person in political life in the province of British Columbia. Like all British Columbians, he did not hesitate to share his opinions, whether they were contrary or in favour of where you stood in public life.
During the brief period of time that I was premier of the province of British Columbia, Senator van Roggen and I disagreed on almost every single issue. In every instance he was a perfect gentleman. I hope people can say the same about me.
There is a spirit of British Columbia that perhaps separates us from other regions as their spirit separates them, but in our province bluntness, frankness and openness is a hallmark of some of the tremendous leaders in our province.
The one comment that I want to make on the area that we agreed on completely was in the expansioned Asia Pacific. Senator van Roggen was a forceful speaker throughout Canada for our position and its peculiar needs in Asia Pacific.
Senator van Roggen will be greatly missed, but he will be remembered lovingly as the kind of British Columbian who comes to the province, becomes totally absorbed in Canada and in British Columbia and gives full measure of his life to the area that he comes from and to all people in this country.

subtopic: THE LATE SENATOR GEORGE CLIFFORD VAN ROGGEN
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, firt of all, I want to thank you for your kindness in giving me this opportunity to say a few words about Senator van Roggen, whom I have known since 1964.
He was a proud citizen of your majestic province. To know him was to know the other person's point of view. The previous speaker, Mr. Barrett, said that one could disagree with him, and I know he himself did. However, although one could profoundly disagree with some of Senator van Roggen's positions, in the process one came to understand the real meaning of democracy and friendship.
I had the good fortune to know him as far back as 1964, and in 1968, at the convention where we were both on the same side-not on the winning side, I admit-I started to understand what was meant by western pride. In all modesty, I hope that our friendship also helped acquaint him with the point of view of a French Canadian from Quebec, which I am, have always been and shall remain.
I think students would do well to read the lengthy reports of the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs which the senator chaired so brilliantly. The reports on Canada's relations with the Middle East and on free trade are still very topical and also interesting for what they reveal about the personality of Senator van Roggen, whose passing we mourn today.
June 10, 1992

We wish to extend our sincere condolences to his wife Jane and his children, and we hope that many parliamentarians will be able to take the time to show their regard and appreciation for the true aristocrat we learned to know so well.

subtopic: THE LATE SENATOR GEORGE CLIFFORD VAN ROGGEN
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I mourn as well personally for the late Senator George van Roggen and want to add a word about my own contact with him over the decades, not as a close friend but certainly as one who was a great admirer of his.
Senator van Roggen has been spoken of here today as a great Canadian and as a great British Columbia and, of course, he will be remembered in those regards.
I think of him also as a great Liberal, one who contributed to the stream of thought which characterizes the evolution of ideas within the Liberal Party.
George was a great contributor of ideas, a stalwart who stuck to his guns, had a very firm view of how this nation should evolve, and whether our party ended up agreeing or disagreeing with him he remained loyal to us. At a time when Liberals were strong in Toronto perhaps but not so strong in the west, he remained one who would always stand up and carry our banner forward. I think in that all members would agree, in keeping any political party strong and helping to strengthen the democracy of Canada.
I will miss also a man of great personal courage who was constantly in pain, yet constantly ready as someone in the other place said like a teenager, constantly ready to come forward with enthusiasm to put his ideas on the table, to debate them, to engage your own ideas, to try again and again to carry forward his own Liberal vision of our country.
He was a wonderful example and I was inspired by him when I first arrived. As I got older and older, I watched him remain as young, enthusiastic and committed to putting forward ideas and winning arguments as ever.
He was a pioneer in his part of the country. He is an inspiration to young Candians, he is an inspiration within our party, someone of whom we will always be very proud, and someone whom we shall miss.

speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to report to the House today on the latest developments in the situation in Bosnia and Hercegovina and on my recent meetings in Europe.
I want to talk about peacekeeping in this context and in the context of the UN Secretary General's efforts to secure the Sarajevo airport. I will also talk about our continued participation in the peacekeeping operation in Cyprus.
The situation in Bosnia-Hercegovina has deteriorated to the point where even relief convoys are attacked with impunity. This is a direct challenge to the credibility of the UN's current peacekeeping operation. For this reason and after considerable thought, we have agreed to a request from the UN Secretaiy-General that in the event the ceasefire holds he reassign Canadian peacekeepers to keep the Sarajevo airport secure to allow humanitarian relief to reach the general population.

The mechanized infantry batallion of 850 Royal 22nd Regiment soldiers will be redeployed from Croatia once circumstances permit.
The first phase of the Secretary-General's plan for securing the Sarajevo airport is already underway with the deployment of 60 unarmed military observers today under the command of Canadian General Mackenzie.

June 10, 1992
Routine Proceedings
On the basis of the mission's assessment, the security council will decide if conditions permit entering into the second phase of this operation. These conditions were established by the UN last Friday with Serbian, Bosnian moslem, and Croatian parties to the conflict: That artillery and anti-aircraft weapons capable of reaching the airport be withdrawn and placed under UN supervision.

We fervently hope the mission can achieve the conditions necessary for the deployment of UN forces.
This may continue to be a difficult situation to manage. As on numerous occasions since the beginning of the Yugoslav conflict, risks of the cease-fire collapsing are very high. It is also imperative that the UN protect the humanitarian operation once forces have been deployed.
Dangers will still exist in Sarajevo, but our Canadian forces leadership has determined that these difficult assignments are feasible provided initial conditions can be satisfied. I believe that Canada had to respond favourably and actively to the Secretary-General's request, after considerable thought about the implications.
His decision is consistent with our commitment to bring an end to the fighting in Bosnia and bring relief to the innocent. It is also consistent with the statements we have made and the calls to action that we have given to the United Nations throughout the tragic series of events over the past months.
It also confirms that our commitment to security in Europe remains undiminished. I was able to reinforce this commitment during a series of meetings in Europe last week.
NATO made an historic decision in Oslo. In the past, NATO's role was to provide security against attack on alliance members from the countries in the east.
Today, those same countries in the east look to NATO for security from attacks by each other or from ethnic and nationalist violence resulting from the breakup of the Soviet empire.
We trust that our common commitments to the principles of the CSCE-democracy, the peaceful settlement of disputes and, above all, the legal acceptance and tolerant treatment of minorities-will be a formula for
peace. However, if there is a need to resolve conflicts through peacekeeping all of Europe welcomes the application of NATO's unique abilities to provide real resources and expertise.
In Oslo NATO agreed to consider just such CSCE requests. In my view this could well prevent Yugoslav-type tragedies from occurring in the future.
Canada was one of the originators of the concept of peacekeeping. Since the 1950s Canada has served in virtually all UN peacekeeping operations. At this moment Canadians serve around the world, in the Middle East, Cyprus, Central America, Europe and Cambodia.

The most important test of the effectiveness of peacekeeping is the length and strength of the peace once the peacekeepers have gone. Our troops have been with the UN peace-keeping force in Cyprus for 28 years. Clearly this is not a model for peacekeeping.
The absence of peace must not be allowed to contaminate the relations between new generations of old rivals.

I have just visited Cyprus and discussed the situation there with its president and with my colleagues in Ankara and Athens. I said that unless there is progress toward a solution Canada would withdraw its forces.
I can report that in this case there is some progress. Over the next few weeks, and the next couple of months, a set of ideas will be discussed among leaders to establish the basis for peace without peacekeepers.
As a result of this positive development Canada will not completely withdraw its forces this year. However, we must take this opportunity to force the search for a definitive settlement of a long-standing grievance, which has gone on for far too long.
While in Cyprus I had the privilege of visiting the Canadian forces assigned to Nicosia in their role as peacekeepers. I also had a chance to visit the troops on duty and in their barracks right in the peacekeeping zone, in the buffer zone in Nicosia.
I was able to see firsthand the very high degree of professionalism that they display and the fact that it is recognized and appreciated by all of the parties to this dispute, by all sides. All Canadians should be very proud of their actions and the honour that they bring to our country.
June 10,1992

However, the risk of conflict in the world in the coming years remains real. Our challenge will be to make the UN and regional organizations respond in timely and effective ways. We are very sensitive to the fact that some of these decisions will be difficult and that risks to the safety of soldiers and civilians will be high.
The financial burden will also be higher than in the past. Canada may not be in a position to participate in every mission as it has in the past.
How we contribute to peacekeeping missions in the future may also vary. However, we must encourage changes in the international institutions and in the international management of peacekeeping, and we must be flexible in our support of peacekeeping operations.
Canada has a long and distinguished tradition of leadership in peacekeeping and we intend to retain that position in the UN, in NATO and in the CSCE. However we must also build on those efforts in the newer area of peacebuilding and the negotiated settlement of potential conflicts before they erupt into violence. We look to the CSCE summit in Helsinki this summer to consolidate progress in peacebuilding for Europe.
[Translation}
In the months ahead, as our Canadian peacekeepers continue to provide a measure of stability in troubled areas of the world, we must work vigorously to identify and resolve the underlying motives and forces which generate conflict in the first place.

We must not squander the opportunity that history has afforded us. I can assure this House and all Canadians that Canada will continue to be in the forefront of the movement toward global peace. I will continue to report diligently on our progress toward that end.

Mr. Speaker, first let me say that we welcome the discussion that the minister has introduced on the serious situation in Bosnia-Hercegovina and other parts of former Yugoslavia. We appreciate the minister reporting to the House on her visit. We share, as do many other Canadians, the incredible sense of tragedy and sadness at watching the
Routine Proceedings
unmitigated and unrestrained killing that goes on day after day, especially of helpless people.
We also want to join in complimenting the Canadian peacekeepers who are serving that region. We often debate the role of the Armed Forces, but there can be no more significant role that our Armed Forces are playing today than in the interventions they are making in several spots around the world, such as Cambodia, Cyprus, Yugoslavia, the Middle East and other areas. It is unquestionably one of the real contributions that Canada can make to peace.
At the same time there is also sadness because the breakdown and failure that is happening in Yugoslavia represents the world's inability to make an effective response. This conflict did not just occur this week. It has been happening for well over a year. There is no question that the response of the western community- the Europeans, Americans, Canadians and others-has been far too little and far too late.
We only have to compare the reaction to the way in which the western community responded to the invasion in Iraq, when there were immediate sanctions within days. Yet it took months upon months for us to get our act together in Yugoslavia. We knew that conflicts were emerging.
In this House only three weeks ago I posed a question to the minister asking for the withdrawal of diplomatic approval of the regime in Belgrade and the minister refused to do it.
The minister was overturned in three days by the Prime Minister, but the fact of the matter is that we have been reluctant and slow in our reactions. We have not understood the important precedents that this incredible conflict sets. All those brave words about the new world order that we heard after the Iraqi conflict have given real cause to the sceptics to ask what has gone wrong.
The international community has not responded to protect the basic human rights of people in Croatia or Bosnia. I suppose we are making the same mistake in the emerging conflict in Kosovo, another part of that tragic region. Again nothing is being done to prevent the conflict from emerging.

June 10, 1992
Routine Proceedings
Even last week when we again raised specific questions in the House of Commons directly to the Prime Minister, asking whether the Government of Canada was prepared to support active intervention in Sarajevo by the United Nations to deal with humanitarian relief, he refused to answer.
We were not prepared to take a stand or to take leadership on that crucial issue. We were waiting, holding back. Therefore, while we must pay brave tribute to the peacekeepers I am afraid that the policy makers are not giving them the kind of support they deserve. We are not responding in the way that is required to build a new regime of security.
I noticed with interest that the minister said in her statement that the meetings at Oslo this past week confirmed a new role for NATO to take under the CSCE. Once again the government was confirming that the CSCE might be able to prevent future Yugoslavias from happening.
Why is it not being asked to step in on this conflict taking place now? If there is now an agreement that NATO troops could be used under CSCE direction why is Canada not asking for a CSCE meeting immediately to discuss the problem of whether there will have to be further actions taken to stop the fighting, not just in Sarajevo and not just to provide humanitarian relief but to stop the conflict throughout that whole area?
Once again we are laying back, holding back and reserving. We are not initiating, not taking leadership, and not moving into the vacuum that is clearly there when we know that more blood will be spilled and more innocent lives will be lost.
The minister says that we must prevent further conflicts. Yet the minister's own department withdrew its funding, under this year's estimates, from the centre for conflict prevention of the CSCE. How can we stand in the House and say that we are fully committed and we are going to do everything we can to stop the conflict while the Government of Canada has withdrawn funding from one of the major new initiatives that the CSCE has sponsored?
It is hard to reconcile the rhetoric with the action or the action with the rhetoric. The two simply do not mix.
Maybe it is not the minister's fault, it may be her colleagues who are the problem. However, we cannot have the Department of Finance making crucial foreign policy decisions and nickel and diming on the crucial issue of international security. That is what is taking place.
Even in today's debate the minister said in the final part of her statement that it may not be possible for Canada to be involved in future peacekeeping because we may not have the financial support to do so.
The minister said that there may not be sufficient support or funding for these actions, yet at the same time the government is talking about spending $4.5 billion on a piece of military equipment that is already obsolescent. We are no longer engaged in anti-submarine warfare because the submarines are not there any more.
It may be that we need good helicopters for peacekeeping missions because one of the problems that our own peacekeepers found in Croatia, and are certainly finding in Cambodia, is the lack of equipment and the lack of proper logistical support. The UN Secretary General and UN officials have said repeatedly that our inability to mount full peacekeeping ventures and provide the proper support is a result of the lack of funding.
We know the Americans are withdrawing. They are in arrears by close to $800 million. Even our own government in its defence review gave only one line in the entire review to peacekeeping. The end result is that we have a minister rushing off to buy helicopters that are no longer necessary while we are not tailoring the configuration of equipment or support that our own forces will need if they are going to engage in a number of' peacekeeping ventures around the world.
That should be our priority. Our primary objective should be to support international efforts and international collective security, not to be engaging in ghost conflicts left over from the cold war.
I want to raise concerns with the minister about the statements or policies emanating in a variety of ways about Cyprus.
It is not good enough to say we have been there too long. We must ask ourselves whether the fighting will resume if the United Nations withdraws? What is the point of withdrawing if the conflict has not been resolved? What do we gain by creating another serious
June 10, 1992

confrontation between two groups who have not resolved their differences?
If we are talking about withdrawing our troops, surely t.he obligation is to ensure that we are leading the initiative to try to resolve that conflict and, if need be, to stay there until it is resolved. We stood at NATO for close to 45 years to stop a conflict in Europe or a potential invasion. Surely, our patience on peacekeeping deserves the same end.
I do not deny and I do not in any way reject the minister's statement that we must be more diligent in trying to resolve the conflict but I do not think it is to be done by threatening to withdraw troops. That is not the way to build a peacekeeping venture.
I will conclude by saying that I think this whole situation and the lack of action, the lack of funding and the lack of support demonstrate that if we are not careful that great Canadian invention called peacekeeping which Lester Pearson put forward at the UN in 1956 could be in very serious trouble. It could really be in danger of losing its credibility and effectiveness to protect peace in this changing world.
I would like to recommend to the minister, because we were the authors of the original idea of peacekeeping, we should maybe author the reconstitution, the redefinition of peacekeeping.
We are going to have to get new mandates for the United Nations and for regional organizations so that troops going into dangerous situations know that there is a risk and are going to have to be prepared to accept it.
We are going to have to deal with the crucial question of funding. It may be that Canada should initiate calling a major international conference on peacekeeping so that the major countries involved can come together and discuss and decide on peacekeeping.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: The hon. member has had a minute and a half more than the minister has had right now. Please wind up.

I will just simply say that we should have learned our lessons at this point and without any criticism say that Canada does have a a special responsibility and a particular role to
Routine Proceedings
play in helping the world come to grips with the importance of peacekeeping and peacemaking.
We could initiate and take responsibility for bringing concerned countries together and put to them their responsibilities to pay for the important role peacekeeping provides and to redefine the mandate the UN should have redefined. That way it is not simply a matter of sending troops overseas; it is also making sure that the governments of this world, through the United Nations, will make sure those troops have the best equipment and the best support possible.

Mr. Speaker, I too want to express my appreciation to the minister for her statement today which gives the House an opportunity to comment on some of the very serious, very important and very tragic events which are taking place in Bosnia-Hercegovina today.
I want to take this opportunity on behalf of my New Democratic colleagues to respond to two or three of the points raised by the minister and to raise a couple of other issues as well in this context.
First of all, with respect to the situation in Bosnia-Hercegovina, many Canadians have been asking themselves why it is that the community of nations has been unable to respond to the tragedy, to the bloodshed, to the violence, to the death that has taken place there and why it is, in particular, that our government to which we look for leadership has been so slow in responding to this tragedy.
It was almost a month ago that the member for Winnipeg South Centre and I urged the minister to act and to show some leadership on behalf of Canadians.
I asked the minister specifically, in view of the desperate need of the people of Bosnia for food and medicine: "Will Canada support the very urgent request by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for UN troops to protect the humanitarian convoy which will be able to bring in food and medicine to the people of Bosnia?"
That was on May 12. It is now a month later and we are finally, at last, responding to the desperate plea of the United Nations and others for assistance to enable us to get humanitarian aid to Bosnia-Hercegovina. The reality is that too much blood has been shed and too many lives have been lost while the community of nations has failed to respond effectively through the United Nations to this crisis.

June 10, 1992
Routine Proceedings
I would note as well that the minister refused to take even the minimal steps that we called for at that time in terms of the withdrawal of our ambassador after the European Community had taken that step. It was only after the Prime Minister returned from a visit to George Bush that he announced, not the Secretary of State for External Affairs, but he announced that we were taking this action.
I have to ask: Where is the leadership? What role is Canada playing in ensuring a significant supply of humanitarian aid, particularly food and medical aid, to assist the people who so desperately need that aid? There are over 1.3 million refugees, many of whom have moved into Bosnia from Croatia and are in desperate need. I have to ask our government to do far more in terms of humanitarian aid, particularly food and medical aid, in this time of need.
There are other issues as well. There is the whole question of the very difficult situation in Kosovo and the question of the delay of this government in establishing diplomatic relations with Croatia and Slovenia. The government announced some time ago that we recognized the independence of these countries and Canadians welcomed that. But why is it that this government has failed to establish formal diplomatic relations with Croatia and Slovenia? Why is that? There is no explanation in terms of diplomatic relations.
As well, I believe many Canadians are asking for our government to exercise great caution with respect to the recognition of the former Yugoslavian Republic of Macedonia, now Skopje. Canadians are also seeking assurances that there will be full constitutional and political guarantees that there are no territorial claims against Greece and that the name Macedonia, which implies territorial aspirations, is not used. We are looking for those guarantees as well in the context of this discussion.
The minister visited Cyprus. As the member for Winnipeg South Centre and the minister pointed out, I am sure we all want to pay tribute to our peacekeeping troops who have been there for at least 28 years and to our other peacekeeping troops in Croatia and around the
world. However, it does not help at all to achieve a peaceful solution to this long conflict to threaten that we will simply unilaterally pull out our troops.
I know the minister is now saying that we are not going to pull out our troops before the end of this year, although she seems to imply we might pull out some. She said: "We are not pulling them all out before the end of this year". Does that mean the minister is going to pull out a number of Canadian troops? There is a real risk that this could simply aggravate the conflict.
Our role surely is to urge negotiations and again to provide leadership with respect to a negotiated and peaceful solution.
As I mentioned, our peacekeeping troops are doing fine work, whether it be in Croatia, Cyprus or elsewhere. But it has been pointed out by Canadian military officials, in fact Sergeant Mario Grenier who has helped to train Canadian peacekeepers in Yugoslavia said: "We are sending unqualified people to do qualified jobs. We do not have enough training when it is time to get jobs like this done". He has urged that Canada provide more training for our peacekeeping troops.
I want to take this opportunity to urge our government, in the context of this debate, to look very seriously at the establishment of a peacekeeping training centre at Canadian Forces Base Cornwallis in Nova Scotia. Canada has an outstanding international record in peacekeeping and this is the kind of role that we could play effectively in Cornwallis. Indeed, we committed ourselves to that kind of role in a recent resolution which was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in October 1991.
Finally I would like to say a word about the minister's ringing affirmation of Canada's role in NATO. With the demise of the Warsaw pact, with the effective disappearance of the enemy, NATO strategists, the generals, are obviously searching desperately for a new raison d'etre.
Surely the time has come for Canadians to show leadership with respect to the definition of security, to call for the dissolution of this archaic and outdated and ultimately irrelevant military alliance, and to recognize the Citizens' Inquiry into Peace and Security which held public hearings across Canada.
June 10, 1992

We should be redefining the concept of common security. Canadian security policy should be focused on strengthening regional security bodies, strengthening the CSCE, strengthening the United Nations, ensuring that the United Nations is properly funded and that peacekeeping forces are properly funded. In Cambodia right now, the United Nations peacekeeping operation is in danger of foundering because of the lack of proper funding.
At a time when NATO is clinging to a policy of the first use of nuclear weapons, at a time when NATO insists that we in fact not adopt a policy of nuclear weapons-free harbours in Canada, at a time when NATO continues to have low-level flight testing over Innu land, surely now more than ever, it is time for us to recognize that Canada's role should be within the United Nations, a strengthened United Nations and the CSCE and pushing for a comprehensive test ban treaty.
In closing, Canada does have an important leadership role to play in Bosnia-Hercegovina within the United Nations and ultimately in redefining the concept of security on this globe to ensure that when we talk about security we are talking about the right to food, to shelter, to health care, to education, to human rights, to a clean and sustainable environment and to a world at peace.

Mr. Speaker, I have a number of petitions to present today. One of them deals with the Court Challenges Program.

These petitioners come from all over Canada and I am pleased to table this petition in their names.

Mr. Speaker, I have another petition dealing with housing problems.
The petitioners would like to draw the attention of the House to the following. Many Canadians are experiencing serious housing problems. The Government of Canada terminated the federal Co-operative Housing Program on February 25, 1992. The federal non-profit co-op housing program was highly successful in creating a healthy mix in communities. The action of this government has eliminated 2,000 co-op units for 1992 alone, along with 4,000 construction and manufacturing jobs in the same period.
Therefore the undersigned humbly pray and call upon Parliament to urge the government to reinstate the federal Co-operative Housing Program immediately and to commit the $6.1 million to the program which had been planned for 1992 and permit approximately 2,000 co-op housing units to be sponsored this year.
June 10, 1992

Mr. Speaker, I have two petitions to present, both of which are involved with current and ongoing issues.
One deals not only with the specific murder of Nina de Villiers on August 9, 1991, but also with a move to reorient the justice system.
I know that her mother, Mrs. de Villiers, is going to be in Ottawa tomorrow meeting with the justice minister and the critics for the opposition. She has certainly been a crucial person in literally encouraging thousands of Canadians to sign the petition.
The murder of Nina de Villiers on August 19, 1991, has exposed serious deficiencies in the criminal justice system. There are many vulnerable persons who have little protection under the current system. Women, children and disabled persons are at particular risk.
Crimes of violence against a person are intolerable and constitute the most abhorrent crimes society faces.
Current criminal law does not require bail hearings in crimes of violence to be presided over by judges.
Current criminal law may require only a simple signature on a document with no money posted as surety for the release of accused perpetrators of crimes of violence.
Current criminal law does not hold agents of the Crown directly accountable to the public for their actions or omissions in permitting known offenders and accused with violent backgrounds to be free, or in failing to seek orders prohibiting possession of weapons.
Sentencing in crimes of violence does not appropriately reflect society's abhorrence of violence in order to act as a true deterrent and to protect the public by removal of offenders from society. The risk to society proposed by early releases is of secondary consideration. Statutes governing the criminal justice system in Canada must be revised.
Therefore, your petitioners request that Parliament recognize that crimes of violence against persons are serious and abhorrent to society and amend the Criminal Code of Canada, the Bail Reform Act, 1972, and the Parole Act accordingly. I know this petition has the support of literally thousands of Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, my second petition in part has been transcended by events but in part is certainly very relevant to the discussion that

Mr. Speaker, I have the honour to present another petition that was collected by the Glad Day Book Store in Toronto. It notes that in February 1985 the House of Commons mandated the Standing Committee on Justice and Legal Affairs to prepare a report on equality rights in Canada.
In October that committee did prepare that report and unanimously recommended that the Canadian Human Rights Act be amended to prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation in all areas of federal jurisdiction.
The petitioners note that in March 1986 the government promised to accept this report and enact the recommendations. Yet today, some six years later, the recommendations have still not been enacted. They note that other jurisdictions including Quebec, Ontario, Manitoba and Yukon have such protection and that the Canadian Human Rights Commission has called for this protection.
Therefore they call upon Parliament to ensure that government and Parliament act to bring forward immediately an amendment to add sexual orientation to the Canadian Human Rights Act as a prohibited ground of discrimination.
