speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to lead off today's third reading debate on Bill C-48. This bill which amends the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation Act has benefited from a thorough discussion by the House finance committee. A number of very helpful amendments have been made to the bill and I will have more to say about these in a moment.
It will be recalled that this bill expands the range of options available to the government for dealing with troubled financial institutions. Specifically, it gives the CDIC the authority to arrange and carry out the sale of a troubled federally regulated financial institution to a healthy institution.
These new measures which we call the Financial Institutions Restructuring Process or FIRP, were first proposed by the government in the blue paper on financial sector reform. Other major elements of the reforms set out in the blue paper have already been considered and endorsed by this House. It is time now to complete this process of reform and give passage to this remaining piece of legislation.
I will review very briefly why the restructuring powers set out in this bill are needed. As the federal deposit insurers, CDIC can be exposed to substantial potential losses when a member institution gets into financial difficulty and the institution's capital declines.
This legislation helps control CDIC's exposure to loss by giving CDIC the means to act with the approval of the minister in a timely manner to put a troubled institution back on a solid footing. In this way, the new powers will make it possible to run a more cost-effective deposit insurance system.
A fundamental goal of providing these new powers is to enable federal authorities to arrange a restructuring transaction which preserves the value of a troubled institution as much as possible. This is in the best interests of the institution's depositors and creditors and the deposit insurer.
Generally speaking shareholders want to see the value of their institution maintained. But once a deposit-taking institution's capital falls below a certain level, shareholders may find themselves in a position where they have little left to lose by the institution's further decline.
At this stage, declines in the value of the assets of the institution will be borne more and more by the creditors of the institution, its uninsured depositors and the deposit insurer.
Bill C-48 contains measures to deal with this situation and give federal authorities more control over the cost of resolving a financial institution's difficulties.
The restructuring process vests all ownership of the troubled institution in CDIC and gives CDIC the power to approve a restructuring proposal, including the sale of the shares of the institution or the sale of its assets and liabilities.
It is important to understand how CDIC will carry out this role. CDIC will be guided by the objectives set out in its act. In particular, the CDIC Act directs the corporation to promote the stability and competitiveness of the financial system in Canada and to pursue its objectives in a way which minimizes CDIC's exposure to loss.
What this will mean in practice is that when CDIC is faced with a situation of a member institution in serious difficulty, it will consider its range of options, including the new restructuring process, and make a decision based on how best to achieve its corporate objectives.
June 10, 1992

The House finance committee studied the bill very carefully and served an important role by suggesting ways in which the bill could be improved. Witnesses who appeared before the committee also made valuable contributions with their expert knowledge of the financial system.
I would like to take a few moments to describe some of the more important amendments that the committee made.
One category of change was in respect of the bill's stay of proceedings. A number of technical changes were made to this section in consultation with representatives of the chartered banks, trust and loan companies, representatives of the Canadian Depository for Securities Limited and the Canadian Payments Association.
The changes reflect the complexity of financial market systems and products, and with the benefit of the considerable technical knowledge and practical experience of these groups, the bill has been improved.
Changes to the stay of proceedings also reflected a balancing of the interests of ordinary creditors of financial institutions and the interests of financial institutions that act on behalf of other institutions in the clearance and settlement system.
Another group of changes which originated with members of the House finance committee is intended to give federal authorities greater flexibility to arrange a restructuring transaction. These changes centre on the sale of a troubled institution's assets and the transfer of its liabilities, rather than the sale of its shares. Having greater flexibility to structure a deal will mean that CDIC will be able to obtain the highest possible value for the troubled institution and minimize CDIC's exposure to loss.
Finally, the bill was amended to authorize the federal government to enter into agreements with provincial governments regarding provincial institutions whose deposits are insured by CDIC. We will be working with individual provinces that have an interest in the FIRP process to make the appropriate arrangements.
The latter amendment to the bill reflected a concern of the House finance committee that CDIC as the
Government Orders
deposit insurer of most provincial institutions should have additional flexibility to work out problems with these institutions as well. I think the outcome in this case is positive for the financial system.
The amendments have improved the bill, but they do not either individually or collectively change the fundamental policy embodied in the bill.
The broad concept of FIRP was supported by witnesses who appeared before the committee. There was also broad support for giving federal authorities the power to control their exposure to loss when an insured financial institution risks failing.
During the second reading debate on this bill the need for balance in legislation such as this was noted. I would like to take this opportunity to acknowledge the committee's contribution to the balance which has been achieved in Bill C-48.
Before I finish my remarks I would like to note briefly the other provisions contained in Bill C-48 which are not directly related to the financial institutions restructuring process.
The first of these is aimed at improving the flow of information about deposit insurance to customers of financial institutions. The new rules are an important step toward improving the public's understanding of deposit insurance coverage and the changes are welcomed by the industry.
Another section provides for an increase in CDIC's borrowing limit from the Consolidated Revenue Fund to $6 billion reflecting the growth in deposits in recent years.
Other provisions of the act give CDIC greater flexibility to make by-laws to promote a common standard of business practice and conditions of insurance coverage among member institutions.
All of these modifications to the CDIC Act were endorsed by the House finance committee.
I would like to express my appreciation for the contribution of all who participated in the debate in this House on Bill C-48 and those who took part in the study of the bill in committee. I hope hon. members will join me now in supporting this bill by giving it third reading.

June 10, 1992
Government Orders

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to speak on Bill C-48, an amendment to the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation Act.
Most Canadians do not think much about fire insurance until the neighbour's house bums down. Then they make sure they have adequate coverage. Probably the same could be said for life insurance. Most Canadians do not worry too much about it until a friend or a family member dies. Then they wonder if their dependants are provided for.
It is no surprise then with the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation that Canadians really do not think very much about it. This corporation insures deposits in banks and trust companies for Canadians so that in case of a financial fire that results in the financial death of a bank or trust company, Canadians are protected.
Canadians certainly want CDIC to have all the tools that it needs to properly do its job. That job of course is stabilizing the Canadian financial system and protecting Canadians. The legislation we are debating today certainly helps in that regard.
This legislation gives the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation the power to go into a financial institution that is just inches away from bankruptcy and to merge it with a healthy institution or to otherwise restructure it and get it on a firm footing.
We on this side of the House certainly agree that the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation needs this tool. In fact Justice Willard Estey recommended this in his report in 1986 when he reported on the failure of two western banks. The Canadian regulator of banks, trusts, loan and insurance companies, known as the Superintendent of Financial Institutions, also said that Canada very much needs this tool.
He also indicates that he has been very frustrated with the authority he has now. The situation now is that the superintendent either has to shut down a financial institution facing bankruptcy or stand by and watch it fail.
In other words, there is no in between where the regulators could help save a financial institution from going under. I guess it is something like a doctor saying that he had only two choices: to sit back and watch the patient suffer a slow death or put the patient out of his misery once and for all, even though an operation might have saved that person.
This is the situation that the superintendent finds himself in now. Certainly, as I said, he agrees that his office should have this tool or this power which we are giving through Bill C-48. Now regulators will have the option of going in and trying to get this institution on to a firm basis.
The Canadian financial service industry is one of the healthiest in the world. Very seldom do we read in newspapers stories of financial institutions in great difficulties, but recently we have had First City Trust, an Ontario trust company, in the news as well as Central Guaranty.
I suppose we could say that part of this is due to the recession because a recession brings high unemployment and high bankruptcy rates. In my province of Prince Edward Island the unemployment rate is over 19 per cent, the highest ever recorded in that province since Statistics Canada started keeping records.
As well as recessions taking their toll on the unem-plojment rate, they certainly take their toll on financial institutions. Customers of financial institutions are the people who buy cars and homes or borrow to run businesses. When people lose their jobs in a recession it means that many of them cannot make their payments on their cars, their houses or whatever they have borrowed for. They may lose these assets and lose their hope along with them.
Last month the unemployment rate in Canada was 11.2 per cent, the highest since November 1984. The lost jobs and the lost wages I have been talking about will lead to loan payments not being made. If that happens and if enough large borrowers cannot make their payments then financial institutions could be in trouble.
Certainly we saw Standard Trust go that way last summer. This summer Central Guaranty and First City are struggling to avoid Standard's fate. This legislation will help to avoid that by giving the regulator the power to go in and to operate or to help keep the financial institution from going under.
In so doing, we are protecting the 400,000 Canadians who are employed in the banks and in the trust, loan and insurance companies. We must preserve these jobs because we have approximately 1.5 million Canadians out of work. Every job in this country is important and must be protected. As I said, I appreciate the need for this legislation and I agree with what the legislation is going to do, but I certainly have serious concerns about
June 10, 1992

the whole process this government followed to reach the stage where we are today.
First, this legislation is not just needed today. It was also needed five years ago when Mr. Justice Estey recommended it in his report.

The purpose of Bill C-342 is to amend the Income Tax Act so that teachers across Canada can deduct some employment expenses in calculating their income.
For example, they could deduct expenses incurred to take part in professional development days and travel expenses to attend conferences. Let me now give the reasons why teachers should be allowed to deduct some employment expenses.
Private Members' Business
First, teaching at the primary, secondary and post-secondary levels is an occupation that requires higher than average expenses to obtain material, services and facilities related to their teaching duties and to upgrading their academic qualifications and professional skills. While curriculum related material is normally supplied by the employer, teachers must often buy books, periodicals and other written material particular to the teaching profession.

I think it is quite unfair for the Income Thx Act and regulations to allow self-employed professionals and business people deductions for operating expenses and improving their office or business and to refuse these same tax breaks to members of the teaching profession.
Since teachers have considerable employment expenses and play an important role in society, the government must give them the treatment they deserve.

I am presenting this bill this evening as a result of conversations I have had with members of the New Brunswick Teachers' Association, the Canadian Teachers' Federation and teachers themselves who are concerned with expenses. I have a background in education so I can speak from my experience as well.
Elementary, secondary and post-secondary teaching is an occupation which requires larger than average expenditures by teachers on materials, services and facilities related to their jobs and to their professional improvement.
While curricular materials are normally provided by the employer, other equipment and materials related to the professional practice of teaching must be supplied by teachers. Many teachers incur considerable expense for in service professional improvement. They purchase computers and software for educational use in the home and for use in the classroom. As a result of these outlays for these kinds of goods and services, teachers are able to

Private Members' Business
improve their teaching methods and extend to their students a better quality of service.
It is unfair that self-employed professionals and business people are permitted under the Income Thx Act and regulations to deduct expenses of operating and improving their businesses while teachers are denied similar tax benefits.

To be fair and honest, sometimes the perception of teachers is not always positive. Many people in the public sometimes think negatively towards our teachers. Mind you, there are some bad teachers out there but I say to Canadians in general that the majority of teachers and educators are honest, sincere and dedicated to education. I say also that if there is a bad apple out there, then you get rid of it. If there are bad teachers in the system, then you have them removed. I would like to speak about a few specific examples of the involvement of teachers and the expenses they have.

Again, that is an expense that translates into a very positive expense because it is going to be beneficial to our citizens of tomorrow who are our youth. As we know, education has been a major topic of late and a major concern of many especially when we talk about competition and the ability of our labour force to be well trained.
I have taught from grade 1 to grade 12. In my 12 years of teaching I had to attend various workshops. I lived in northern New Brunswick and most of these courses were away from our community. Quite often we had to travel by car for most of these courses. Quite often we car

pooled, obviously. We had to travel and it was an expense. We had to pay for our meals. We had to pay our hotel rooms, but again it was an expense that we met very gladly in the sense that we knew it was going to be beneficial not only to us, but to our students in the classroom.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to speak to Bill C-332.1 must admit I agree with some of the comments made by the hon. member for Restigouche-Chaleur. However, there are other areas where I think he has taken the wrong approach.
If we consider the education system in this country, we must admit it is one of the best in the world. It is also a fact that our education system is our assurance of progress. In the long run, it makes for the best possible economic growth.
I think all members of this House will agree that for any country education is a priority. As I said before, we are privileged in that respect here in Canada.
However, the bill introduced by the hon. member for Restigouche-Chaleur raises a number of problems from the point of view of fiscal justice and fairness. If we go back to the time before our 1988 tax reform, every employee across the country was entitled to a lump sum deduction of $500. As long as we had employment income on our return, we could deduct $500. It was a deduction. As a result, Mr. Speaker, depending on the individual's employment income, the $500 meant an after-tax saving of $100, $150 or $250. If my income was taxable at 50 per cent, I would pay taxes on that amount less $500, which would mean a saving of $250. However, if my income was taxable at 25 per cent, the $500 deduction would mean a saving of only $125.
The 1988 tax reform made the tax system fairer and more equitable. We eliminated anything that could be qualified as a deduction and replaced it with a tax credit. In determining the amount allowed for the basic personal tax credit, we took into consideration the old $500 deduction. As a result, anyone with an employment income in Canada has a basic tax credit which does not depend on the individual's tax rate but on the fact that he has an employment income.
For instance, if the basic tax credit is $1,000, whatever my employment income happens to be I will pay $1,000 less in taxes. Whether I earn $50,000 or $100,000 or $20,000, I get the same tax credit. My point is, Mr. Speaker, that a tax credit is subtracted from the tax payable.
This means that all Canadians are equal for tax purposes. Whatever the rate at which they are taxed, they have the same tax credit, and that is important.
The hon. member opposite says it is not true. I would advise her to take a course in taxation, and maybe she will understand what is happening in Canada's tax system. It would do her a world of good to take a course on the subject.
June 10, 1992

In any case if she wants the floor, she can have it as soon as I finish. Meanwhile, she could at least let me proceed.
As I was saying, the system has made the Income Tax Act more equitable. The hon. member's proposal suggests adding eight specific deductions to the Income Tax Act, targeted exclusively to the teaching profession. However, this would put unfair practices right back into the Income Tax Act.
This evening, I speak both from my experience as a tax expert and as a professor at the University of Quebec in Trois-Rivieres and in Sherbrooke. When I was teaching, I could only deduct expenses as provided under the Act. That was normal for anyone who had an employment income. Given the privileges my colleague demands in the Income Tax Act, Canadian teachers could specifically deduct eight items he identified as teaching related expenses. I would be quite glad for the teachers, but what will we do about the workers who regularly buy tools for their work and are on salary, or have employment income? What will we do about mechanics who work in a garage, have an employment income and must buy all kinds of tools every year to do their job?
Mr. Speaker, you will understand that I could name any occupation where people are paid a salary and have to buy goods for their work in order to earn employment income. Mr. Speaker, you will see that that is where the unfairness lies. In Canada, we cannot think of giving more to one kind of occupation than to another.
My colleague from Restigouche-Chaleur gives me the example of lawyers. I am glad he does, because I will tell him that lawyers have employment income or a salary and are entitled to no deduction except the one now provided for in the Income Thx Act, which is the same as for teachers. Notaries who are on salary are entitled to no other deduction than what teachers have. We could go through all the professions when we compare employment income with business income.
Private Members' Business
A lawyer who opens an office or starts a business is entitled to claim business related expenses. What the hon. member forgets to point out is that a lawyer who has his own office may not have any income at the end of the year either. He may run a loss. He has no assured income. He has no salary. He has fees if he works and earns them, but if he has no clients. He has no income. Even if he could take all the expenses in the world-

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for International Trade
speechtext: If the clients don't pay.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
speechtext:
My colleague from Kamouraska-Ri-viere-du-Loup, ever the good manager, points out that if the clients do not pay, it comes to the same thing.
We should not confuse what-
In what country do you live? That is not true.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, could you tell my colleague that she will have her turn to speak. Would you please tell her?
That is not true for lawyers. We are three lawyers here. In what country do you live?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
speechtext:
My colleague will find out that we are four lawyers, because I am one too. If she would be so kind as to let me finish my speech it would be appreciated.
We must not confuse what the Income Tax Act considers employment income, a fixed, assured, guaranteed salary, and business income, whether it is a lawyer's office, an architect's office or any profession where the rules for deductions are different. The Income Tkx Act is clear. Any expense to earn business income is deductible. The law is there to help people earn a living, but the teacher or lawyer on salary does not have work related expenses. They are assured of a salary that comes every week.
Employment income and business income are treated quite differently in the tax system.
In conclusion I would like my colleagues in the House to think of the injustice that would be done if this bill were passed. Again I agree with what the hon. member said about the work done by teachers in Canada. I have no problem with that, but we have a big problem with tax

June 10, 1992
Private Members' Business
fairness, if we allow one category of people with employment income to deduct some items they buy for their work, when no one else can do the same.
We would do a grave injustice to all Canadians.
I see that my time is up. I will close by asking hon. members to think carefully about this subject.

Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to support this bill put forward by my colleague and friend, the hon. member for Restigouche-Chaleur.
It is time a bill of this nature was brought forward, and since we could not get it from the government side, then it is only right it should be brought forward by a caring and thinking member of the teaching profession such as my colleague.
I was astounded at the remarks of the parliamentary secretary because I do not know what country he is living in. He made comments about deductions made for some professionals and not for others that are just not true in many cases.
What we have to understand most clearly about this particular situation is who we are talking about here. We are talking about the profession that spends its time, professional life, working time, in dealing with young Canadians, teaching them, moulding their minds and setting an example for them.
Although sometimes it may be hard to believe, every one in this Chamber went to school for some period or another, and we all had teachers. We all know the tremendous influence, the tremendous amount of effort over and above what is required in the job description that teachers put into their jobs.
I have to admit to a bit of special pleading here. I taught for one year and I was also a substitute teacher in the springs of my university years. Most particularly, my mother was a teacher and a principal for 41 years in the school system in Nova Scotia.
I know at very close hand the kind of commitment and sacrifice members of the teaching profession put into their daily lives. There are very few teachers who work solely from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. or whatever the school hours may be. There are endless hours of preparation, endless hours of correcting, endless hours of dealing with students, counselling them, assisting them, being in loco parentis, being surrogate parents to their students, frequently dealing with social problems and difficulties that the home is not prepared to deal with. Our school system, much suffering from cutbacks, is unable to deal in an extra-professional sense and the teachers deal with this as well.
Teachers get a bad rap in the country because, yes, there is no question it is a secure job, and it is a well paid job; but not necessarily the be all and end all of pay. Not when you put it up against the hours that are spent after school is closed in volunteer projects with the students, the hours that are spent during summer vacations in volunteer projects with the students, on weekends, Christmas time, March break, and on and on.
My colleague's bill, which gives teachers, a bit of break, particularly in this overtaxed atmosphere we have in this country today, is not a great deal to ask.
I look in particular at the section of the bill that relates to professional expenses. I find it utterly unbelievable that professional expenses are not deductible for teachers. My colleague on the other side talked about the fact lawyers only get to deduct those expenses which relate to their business. That is not true. Lawyers get to deduct their professional fees no matter what they are doing. They get to deduct their memberships in their bar societies; that is a deductible fee. TTiere are other deductible fees as well.
Or union dues.

Or union dues. You are absolutely right. Union dues for teachers should be deductible as well. Absolutely. A wonderful thing, why can you not move it a little further and do professional fees as well? Why can you not do it for mandatory travel expenses on in service days that no one else is paying for but the teacher? No one else is taking care of their hotel bills and no one else is taking care of their travel expenses. Everyone else in a profession gets that kind of relief.
The teachers in this country deserve a better break and this bill is the kind of a break that can give it to them.
My colleague, having been a teacher himself, understands this. There are colleagues on the other side of the House who you would think would understand this as well. This is not something that is going to add immeasurably to the deficit of this country if you pass this bill. This is not something-
June 10, 1992
$500 million a year.

Five hundred million a year. Show me where you find your figures. I would like to know where you find your figures. I would suggest that he is using an etch-a-sketch rather than a calculator.
This is a fairness issue. If one group of professionals are permitted to behave in this way and to deduct certain things, another group of professionals should be allowed the same thing.
Therefore, it is with the greatest amount of fervour that I say to all members that the private member's bill brought forward by the member for Restigouche-Cha-leur deserves the support of this House, deserves the non-partisan support of both sides of this House. Let us see a little fairness for teachers who do so much and do not get, contrary to a lot of people's opinion, a great deal in return.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to enter into this debate.
I want to say at the outset that earlier this afternoon, as chairman of the finance committee, I tabled a report where we had examined a proposal put forward by the hon. member for Winnipeg-St. James. In his particular case he was suggesting that mechanics be allowed to deduct their tools. During the course of that study we also heard from real estate agents who were suggesting that they should be able to deduct the cost of home computers and car telephones and certain other particular things that they are not able to deduct.
This bill by this particular member is along those same lines. It gives me concern for a number of reasons. First of all, almost everyone suggests that the tax system is too complex, its complexity creates unfairness and in many cases-
CAs get to deduct everything.

Not when they are employees they do not.
If we begin down the track of defining a particular tax regime for every type of occupation whether it is mechanics, teachers, real estate agents, what we are doing is not creating fairness, but creating unfairness. Moreover we are creating enormous complexity because virtually everyone will be treated differently within the tax system. One of the primary objectives of the tax system is
Private Members' Business
that people in similar circumstances will be treated the same.
Members of this House will know, and you will know for certain, Mr. Speaker, that for a male member to speak in the House he must wear a tie. It could be argued that because you must wear a tie to do your job as a member of Parliament, ties for members of Parliament should be deductible. We might have to ask what limit we should put on the price and the amount of deduction; over what period of time should we depreciate them.
I know that that is a bit of a facetious example, but it illustrates the difficulty in trying to determine for particular occupations the types of deductions that might be applicable to them and how one would ever draw a line.
I suspect we would even have to spend a great deal of time trying to define what is a teacher. At first blush one could suggest that teachers are persons employed by school boards or post-secondary education institutions.
There are many other types of institutions that employ teachers in various ways. There are many types of educational institutions, so we would again be in a situation of having to determine who would be eligible for these deductions.
I can tell the member after eight years of experience on the finance committee of this House and several years experience in business before coming to the House involved in the tax system, once you start trying to create those definitions and those delineations you have a great many problems.
I should say it is true that employees, teachers, mechanics and others, have expenses involved in their employment. It is also true that up until 1987 there was a general deduction available for people up to a limit of $500 available to all employees to compensate them basically for those types of expenses without having to try and enumerate which particular occupations, teachers, real estate agents or others would be eligible for them.
That deduction was eliminated in the 1988 tax reform along with a number of other deductions. The employment expense deduction and the $1,000 dividend deduction were eliminated also. They were eliminated to do two things; first, simplify the tax system and second, lower the rate. That is the reason they were done.

June 10,1992
Private Members' Business
They were accepted at that time and received good support among the Canadian people. I should mention in passing that the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood has put forward a tax proposal that he calls the single tax. His proposal would go even further in eliminating even more deductions and would attempt to achieve a single tax rate.
Many people speak quite favourably of that, but I am not certain that it could be achieved. In a survey I did in my own constituency from which I have just been counting the replies, that was one of the questions that I asked and a majority of the respondents suggested that we should have what would be called a flat tax.
In other words, we should be eliminating deductions rather than trying to create new ones. In so far as I am concerned, that is the direction we should be trying to go-
There are other difficulties involved in trying to determine deductions for individual groups of employees or occupations.
In our report tabled today, which I think hon. members would find of interest if they are interested in this particular subject because it is applicable to teachers as it is to mechanics and to people in the real estate business, we have listed the various problems and tried to come to some resolution concerning them.
We came to the conclusion that at the end of the day, the only real resolution would be a deduction that could be offered to all qualifying employees. In other words, they would not be segregated by occupation. The deduction would have to be available to employees in general to meet certain expenses that are involved in their employment.
If we are simply going back to giving everybody a deduction of $500, we could simply lower the tax rate and everybody would be just as well off. I am not so sure that that gains what is being suggested here.
However, it was our recommendation, after analysis and consideration and hearing from witnesses in this area, that the Department of Finance make an attempt again to try to come to some definition of what exceptional expenses could be allowed to be deducted by employees in the course of their employment.
It was suggested a little while ago that lawyers, chartered accountants and other professionals are allowed to deduct the kinds of things that are being sought here. To some degree, that is true but that is only when people are self-employed. There is a distinction.
Employees, receive fixed salaries monthly, weekly, annually; they have income. They also have many other types of benefits that go along with that. They are eligible for unemployment insurance, for example. They make the contributions and if they become unemployed, as former employees they can receive unemployment insurance benefits.
People who are self-employed have no such benefits. They are not available to them and they have no guaranteed salaries. In fact, what they have to do is determine whether or not they can find sufficient income to cover the expenses they have.
In some cases, the expenses that they incur may be more than the revenue they take in and they may actually have a loss on the year or even lose money on the year.
That is not the case for employees. They do not lose money during the course of the year. They may lose their job and thereby their income but they are not obligated to lay out money in advance for expenses that are required in order to earn that income. A lawyer or a doctor may have to do that to rent an office and buy equipment. They might have to spend many thousands of dollars in the hope of earning income, but with no guarantee that they would have the income that is provided when one has a fixed job.
I could speak further on this. It is a subject that we spent a great deal of time on in 1987 in the finance committee when we did the 1987 tax reform. It was generally concluded at that time that we wanted to eliminate as many deductions as possible and reduce the over-all tax rate. That was done in 1987. I believe it was the correct move. I believe it would be a step backward to create again individual deductions aimed at particular groups or particular individuals, which this bill and the earlier bill of the hon. member for Winnipeg-St. James suggested.
June 10, 1992

We want to be very careful. I would suggest that he consult with his colleague in the Liberal Party, the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood, who is going in the opposite direction. In my opinion he is going in a more preferable direction because it would be a system that would be applied to all taxpayers on a basis that would be equally available to them all without determining the particular occupation they are involved in.

Mr. Speaker, I do not intend to speak very long today as I understand the limited time that members have to debate this bill.
There were two things that I wanted to mention. First, I would like to respond to my friend from Edmonton Northwest who spoke about the self-employed versus the employed workers in terms of tools. It reminded me of the position of people who work as carpenters in rural and northern parts of this country. Carpenters for all intents and purposes are self-employed but the only work they can get on a steady basis is working as subcontractors on projects contracted out to general contractors. The general contractors will hire individual carpenters as employees but require them to own their own tools.
For all intents and purposes these carpenters are self-employed but for income tax purposes they are very much an employee. As a result the requirement for the job and the expense is treated much differently than if they were self-employed and paying the taxes, as the hon. member for Edmonton Northwest suggested.
I intend to have a very careful look at the report that the member discussed in his remarks. We will certainly provide him with some input from northern Saskatchewan and the perspective of the individual workers in northwest Saskatchewan. I appreciate the opportunity to be able to do that.
Second, regarding the matter at hand, Bill C-342, I want to commend the member who raised this issue today for his communication skills. Obviously teachers throughout Canada are very much aware of the bill today.
Prior to the bill being introduced this evening I received a couple of letters by fax from teachers within
Private Members' Business
my constituency who indicated their awareness of the matter before us and wanted to communicate their support.
I would like to take this opportunity to put on record the communications I received today. One is from Elaine Yaychuk, who represents teachers in Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan. She indicates the support of the teachers of Meadow Lake for this bill. The second is from an individual teacher named Robert Krismer from North Battleford, Saskatchewan. He is a teacher in the separate school system in North Battleford who communicates his support.
I will read a couple of paragraphs from Mr. Krismer's letter to indicate to the member who put forward this bill and the government the support for this bill that exists among some members of my constituency.
My constituent writes:
Dear Mr. Tkylor, I am writing to you with regard to the bill being introduced to the House on June 10 of this year by the Member for Restigouche-Chaleur, New Brunswick, Mr. Guy Arseneault.
As a teacher, I feel quite strongly that our profession has long been disregarded in this area. Certainly, consideration for deduction of expenses incurred in our area of work would not be a precedent setting move as many other professional, white collar and blue collar workers have been granted this type of concession, in some cases, for quite some time already.
Further, it is not unrealistic to think that many teachers do incur expenses that enable them to be more effective in the classroom, either with the purchase of materials that are used directly in their classrooms or as equipment that help them to plan and prepare for their classes.
He outlines some of his personal expenses like the computer systems he has purchased. He teaches computer literacy classes for grade nine and uses his equipment for storing some of his students' notes. He goes on to say:
In addition to the purchase of this hardware, I have purchased software so I am able to do this work.
As I said earlier, I think it quite reasonable to conclude that, just as many other professions and occupations purchase materials which assist them in their line of work and are able to claim these as expense deductions, teachers should also be considered for such deductions.
I was happy to learn that Mr. Arseneault had advanced such a piece of legislation and I am asking that you support this bill for me and the several teachers I represent as their councillor here in the Battlefords. I thank you.

June 10, 1992
Private Members' Business
Realizing that time is short and members wish to speak I simply want to communicate this information to the House.

Mr. Speaker, I will try to split what time we have left with my hon. colleague from Moncton.
I would begin by saying that I too have received many pieces of correspondence dealing with this particular issue. As a matter of fact the pile is quite thick. It is not an issue that is strange to me.
What is the issue? The issue is somewhat confused. In some of the letters there is a request that professional fees be covered under the Income Tkx Act. Of course that has already been done.
I believe the nub of this issue to be, and I have full and total sympathy for this position, a situation in which teachers are required to go beyond that which is normally defined by the boards of education as a requirement of their jobs.
Teachers are extremely professional in every sense of the term. I know because my wife happens to be a teacher. Not only that, but through her I have met many other teachers.
The mere mention of good teachers versus bad teachers caused me some concern because I think that all teachers are essentially good teachers. They not only convey that which they have learned to tomorrow's leaders but in so doing convey a bit of their hearts, souls and consciences.
What got me involved in this particular subject was a presentation made to me on behalf of a particular teacher who while teaching in a mixed culture school saw that it was an advantage for cross-cultural purposes to teach the children how to make bannock. The school board budget did not permit her to buy flour, sugar and whatever else was needed to make bannock so she brought these materials from her kitchen at home. I wondered whether or not this was going a little bit above and beyond the call of duty. Recognizing that a teacher was doing this, I had to admit teachers would do this normally. Their expectation is that the Government of Canada through the Income Tax Act would some day soon, hopefully sooner than later, recognize this contribution that they make to our upcoming communities. I have no difficulties with that expectation. I do not think
it is greedy at all. It is something that I am hopeful we will see happen very soon.
We talk about moneys being made available for these kinds of programs. Someone said that it was a matter of priorities. Someone asked is it fair that where we are today is where we should be? Should we not have progressed further? Today, as a matter of fact, you will recall that merchant marines performing in World War II have now been classed as full veterans with all veterans' benefits, the sort of thing that I am sure all of us felt should have happened a long time ago, not possessing though the necessary financial mechanics to make it happen. It happened today. I would venture to say that what the teachers are asking for, which will as well affect all those who require tools of the trade or expenditures over and above that which a normal salaried person is required to provide to their job, will some day be recognized. Again, I hope that it happens sooner than later.
I would just take one or two minutes more and say for those not knowing the background of government funding that does occur, through two systems of funding known as EPF and CAP the federal government grants this money to the provinces, which in turn take traditionally used EPF money for education and for hospitalization. The strings are no longer attached to EPF that way. EPF is used by the provinces as they see fit. In negotiating with teachers, with school boards, I would have to ask: Is it fair to expect now that this money has come from the federal government to the provincial governments that they should look at the broader picture of education? Education goes beyond books and pencils, reading, writing and arithmetic. It goes into society, as I have explained earlier.
Is it fair that maybe the school board should pay greater heed to some of these extra costs? Certainly I think we all agree in this Chamber that it is not fair for the teachers themselves to be expected to take their professionalism into the classroom, dig down deep into their pockets and supplement an educational system that will help all of us.
The matter before us is not whether or not the status quo is fair. I think we all agree that it is not fair. Who said that taxation was ever fair? We can only hope to strive to continue to make it fairer. I would hope that the thrust of what we have before us today becomes law in the not too distant future.
June 10, 1992

Mr. Speaker, I thank my colleague opposite for sharing part of the time with me so that I can have an opportunity to speak on this particular bill.
I should say that when you listen to what the government says, in most cases in the response you get you wonder about its commitment to education and its search for excellence in education. If you look at some of the things that teachers are talking about that they would like to have, some relief as far as the tax system is concerned, there are things like educational improvement expenses, such as registration fees and cost of books and travel and living expenses. Or, they want the cost of purchasing teaching materials for audio-visual and those types of things that are not supplied by school boards, and the cost of purchasing equipment such as computers and computer software and the cost of books that are necessary for them to do their jobs.
When you look at those expenses and then you hear some of the members opposite with their excuses, you wonder where their commitment is. If their commitment is to education, obviously their commitment has to be to the teachers, because they are the vehicles utilized in part for this search for excellence in education. We need to show a strong commitment to education and show that commitment to the teachers who are the integral part of delivering that service.
On top of that, a tax system has to be fair and must be seen to be fair. As I listen to the objections, I come to the conclusion that the teachers are talking about fairness as the excuse of continuing to be unfair, rather than trying to correct the unfairness in the system. That could be achieved, quite frankly, by taking a look at this type of exemption. If some day somebody should see the wisdom of doing a flat tax, then all would be treated equal and there would be fairness in the system. We would not have to be requesting these types of items.
I know that my time is short, but I think that it is time to become proactive.
Let us do something positive. Let us send a clear message to teachers in this country that we are with them and we are supportive of them.
I have heard some objections and some concerns as to what may happen. There are some nuances and there are some changes, and those types of things. Maybe the best
Government Orders
place for this would be at a committee to really go through and take a look at those.
If I could get unanimous consent of all my colleagues, I would move a motion that this be referred to a committee, perhaps even the finance committee, to review this bill. I would ask for unanimous consent for a motion that this be moved to the finance committee for study.

speechtext:
